Specifically, he finds that the government has chronically underinvested in workforce training.48
One of the primary reasons for deterrence failure is the absence of active defense options. Deterrence requires Japan to credibly signal that it has both the capability and willingness to launch a punitive action to impose pain on attackers.[49] Drawn from the concept of deterrence via punishment, this approach posits that coercion requires the imposition of unacceptable damages in retaliation for the attack.[50] This approach differs from that of deterrence by denial, which seeks to deter hostile actions by making it infeasible for an aggressor to achieve its objective.[51] In this article, I adopt the deterrence-via-punishment approach in part because the broader literature of cybersecurity has increasingly adopted.[52] It is also consistent with some Japanese experts' view. For instance, Takahisa Kawaguchi explicitly calls on Japan to have a retaliatory capability for the purpose of deterring attacks; he goes as far as to say that Japan should "practice preemptive actions in areas where deterrence does not work," that "as soon as a sign of an attack is detected, vigilant and preemptive actions must be taken in response," and that "credible retaliation and rational sanction against the adversary must also be imposed."[53]
In fact, there are some signs that Japan is considering active defense measures. In 2012, the government outsourced the development of offensive cyber capability to firms like Fujitsu to order a "seek and destroy" malware.[54] Since 2013, the Ministry of Internal Affairs and Communications (MIC) has run the so-called ACTIVE (Advanced Cyber Threats response InitiatiVE) program to set up honeypots in close cooperation with infrastructure services and antivirus vendors. The ACTIVE program has since helped remove malware from infected machines and blocked more infections by blacklisting command and control servers and by taking down malicious websites, leading to the overall reduction of the number of infected devices.[55] In 2019, furthermore, it was reported that Japan would begin to develop computer viruses to counter attacks and work with the private sector to develop malware software to enter targets' backdoor.[56] Japan's overall response, however, is highly muted. In fact, there is no evidence to date that Japan has never deployed active defense capability. The reason rests with three reasons, starting with a legal one.
Legal Obstacle to Deterrence by Active Defense
The first obstacle is in the legal system. In the area of national defense, Japanese laws are known to work in “positive list” format, which allows officials to execute what is written but prohibits what is not. A practice widely recognized by scholars,^{57} this means that whoever fires an active defense measure must have legal permission in advance; without it, their actions can be illegal. The positive list practice becomes a problem when there is not enough clarity about the legality of active defense, starting with the constitution. Although the constitution does not define cyber attack as use of force and therefore not prohibit it in Article 9, it does not allow anyone to launch cyber attack because it has not explicitly authorized it. This is why, as of now, Japan's law enforcement treats cyber attacks as crimes instead of armed attacks until they are attributed to the military forces of another state. Accordingly, the constitution does not extend an explicit authorization to anyone to use the principle of self-defense as a reason to launch countermeasures. Furthermore, the constitution puts into question the legality of cyber “probing,” an act short of penetrating enemy defense, for the purpose of target surveillance. In Article 21, by prohibiting censorship and disclosure of telecommunications secrecy,^{58} the constitution presents a legal ground to treat cyber reconnaissance operations as illegal as signal intelligence.^{59} For this reason, Kawaguchi considers Article 21 more important than Article 9; “the secrecy of communication stipulated in Article 21 of the constitution (and Article 4 of the Telecommunications Business Law) is more strictly interpreted and applied than in other developed countries, making it especially difficult for the government and telecommunications carriers to monitor packet communication.”^{60} This is why, although the MOD and SDF are authorized to monitor some wireless telecommunications, they are not authorized to do so on a vast body of wired digital information.
It is not the constitution, however, that presents the greatest hurdle to active defense; instead, it is the interlocking nature of the system that raises enough questions about the legality of countermeasures. More precisely, it is the multi-layered, entangling nature of existing judiciary practice that has removed the clarity of legal authorization to use countermeasures as a means of deterrence.^{61} It underscores the ambiguity of the penal code, a set of law enforcement rules enacted in 1907, which presents three conditions under which use of force is legal: (1) presence of imminent and illegal threat to the nation, (2) lack of appropriate alternative response, and (3) minimum necessary amount of force to be used (Articles 36 and 37). Like the constitution, the code does not define cyber attacks as use of force, even though they are constantly “imminent” (because they can occur any time), and presents any basis to conduct active defense. In fact, the code places heavy limits on a variety of cyberspace actions that Japan could otherwise take. In Article 168(2), as amended in 2011, the code punishes illegal production of computer virus, including attempts of unauthorized reproduction of digital signatures of public office. Article 233 extends penalty to those who damaged the credit of or obstructed private business by spreading false rumors on the internet. Article 234 protects commercial business by penalizing interference with computer operations. Finally, Article 246(2) punishes profit-makers who manipulate electromagnetic records on the acquisition and loss of property rights.^{62} Many types of active defense measures Japan would adopt are likely to involve some of the above items, making actions like hacking back and dye-packs likely illegal, especially hacking back operations conducted by private companies against cybercriminal infrastructure. The penal code alone places enough ground to reject most option of active defense.
Similarly, lack of specificity hinders the law of Self-Defense Forces (SDF), which spells out duties and restrictions on SDF operations. This is despite the recent organizational adjustments of SDF to cyberspace reality. SDF has, for instance, established the Cyber Defense Group (CDG) as a joint unit under the C4 (Command, Control, Communication and Computers) Systems Command to monitor communications networks. CDG personnel will increase from 220 to 290 by the year 2021. Spending on cyber affairs more than doubled between 2018 and 2019 from US$100 million to US$235 million. SDF has also built cyber defense units in each service branch of the ground, maritime, and aerial components in ways closely aligned with the CDG. However, because of the aforementioned “positiv
list” format, authorization is necessary for the government to deploy SDF. Yet SDF Law remains profoundly unclear about the conditions for force deployment, because it gives SDF no explicit authorization to carry out anything more than passive defense, leaving underspecified the way SDF would be permitted to conduct active cyber defense. The most that SDF is legally permitted to do is to conduct self-defensive kinetic attacks against armed forces of adversaries when the threshold of an armed attack is crossed. However, SDF Law provides no answer to what target the SDF is legally allowed to hit. It is in part because it does not say “whether cyber responses fall under the category of ‘use of force' or ‘use of weapons' for a defense operation.” A hint may be in Article 74 where the prime minister is authorized to order SDF deployed to deal with an imminent threat, but the threat is commonly understood to be kinetic, not digital. No part of SDF Law explicitly empowers SDF to conduct active defense against cyber attacks nor identifies conditions under which SDF would be deployed to counter cyber attacks. Furthermore, no part in the SDF Law empowers any CDG personnel to defend the government networks outside the MOD and that of critical infrastructure within the range of its current mission.
Structural ambiguity essentially functions as a systematic ban on active defense operations in other parts of the legal system. The 1950 Radio Law penalizes those who transmit false messages by using communications facilities, broadly defined, to gain unfair advantage or inflict damage to other person (Article 106) and seek destruction through use of “violence” in violation of the constitution (Article 107). This law does little to keep foreign-based attackers from using force to undermine the communications systems in Japan, although it does discourage domestic actors, government officials included, from taking otherwise necessary action to protect the facilities. The 1984 Telecommunications Business Law punishes those who expose private communications being handled by authorized carriers (Article 179), obstruct telecommunications services (Article 180), and divulge the private information of people without authorization (Article 183). This law places a heavy burden on firms (and government officials working with them) contemplating to conduct active defense; Koichiro Hayashi and Yoshihiro Tagawa argue that the law, by clarifying telecommunications rules for service carriers, keeps non-telecom firms from using the network for unauthorized purposes. The 1999 Act on Prohibition of Unauthorized Computer Access (UCAL) bans computer-related crimes committed through acts of unauthorized computer access. Inapplicable to foreign attackers, it is a set of articles that work with the penal code in penalizing computer fraud and computer destruction. Because most perpetrators are individual hackers and hacking groups, it generates about 200 indictments a year. The 2001 “Provider Responsibility Act” places the heavy responsibility of “due diligence” on internet service providers (ISPs) by penalizing those that “knew that the infringement of the rights of others was caused by information distribution via said specified telecommunications.” The law discourages private firms from willingly assist in the malicious use of digital commons by third parties. It imposes a serious consequence on actors, including government officials, who launch a cyber attack because the attack is likely to go through routers owned by private firms. The 2003 Personal Information Protection Law requires telecommunications firms to clearly describe the purposes of using personal data (Article 15) and make public the purpose of use (Article 18), while it prohibits fraudulent collection and use of personal data (Article 17) and transfer of such data to third parties without consent (Article 23). This law makes it hard for the government to use private firms for intelligence collection purposes and allow them to conduct self-defensive cyber operations. Finally, the so-called “cyber punishment law” applies both to government officials and firms and penalizes those involved in manufacturing, possessing, and planting viruses for the purpose of operating them on people's devices.
In sum, the whole legal problem stifles active defense options in two ways. First, while domestic laws like these have powerful constraints on government activities and individual crimes, it hardly constrains cyber attacks launched by foreign actors. In other words, the laws may be effective against domestic hackers but not foreign ones. Many foreign hackers operate from countries without extradition treaties, such as China, Russia, and North Korea, so Japan's legal options against them are severely curtailed. As such, the legal system stands in ways that essentially condone foreign hackers to
launch attacks toward Japanese networks, while keeping Japanese officials from using active defense to deter attackers. This problem becomes magnified by the problem of attribution, in which Japan would need to prove attackers' complicity to carry out active defense. This is important because, without proper substantiation of cyber attacks, even when Japanese firms were able to trace attacks to originators, foreign governments are always able to invoke plausible deniability to delegitimize Japanese claims.
The other problem is the lack of authority that officials need to have to grant private firms the right to launch active defense measures in self-defense situations. Through layers of aforementioned laws, officials retain a tight control over private businesses' conduct in cyberspace, in part because they fear, according to Hayashi and Tagawa, that if they let one firm conduct active defense, others would do the same against each other.^{72} This worry about digital chaos stands in contrast to the emerging practice outside Japan, especially countries in the Five-Eyes intelligence partnership.^{73} Elsewhere, experts have become more open to risks and opportunities to probe various options. In Japan's case, active defense would require legal reform. But there are three reasons why reform has been absent. First, a new law would have to specify conditions under which countermeasures will be carried out. However, to bind specific acts on a legal document is antithetic to the reality of cyberspace where strategic flexibility is often required -- cyber attacks continue to evolve. Second, reform would require lawmakers to revise all relevant laws, a bureaucratic nightmare that suppresses willingness for change. It would involve a number of government stakeholders, such as the National Police Agency (NPA), Ministry of Internal Affairs and Communications (MIC), and Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry (METI). This is because laws are administered by different agencies. For instance, the Telecommunications Business Law is administered under MIC while UCAL is in the NPA's realm. The seriousness of interagency friction should not be underestimated. Working across agencies to pass a new law would at least engender a significant temporal challenge; if at all, it would not be made fast enough to keep pace with attack method sophistication. Finally, there is no apparent public appetite for national security reform, especially cyber.^{74} A robust civil society and pacifist movement in the postwar period have played a pivotal role in constraining the government from drifting into aggressive national defense policy. The norm community has been so embedded in society that even Shinzo Abe, the longest-serving Prime Minister (2005--6, 2012--20) who advocated constitutional revisionism, failed to get the political process going and garner enough popular support to revise Article 9.^{75} The constitution's Article 96 stipulates that, to revise any part of it requires two thirds of votes in both chambers of the Diet and a national referendum to gain a majority, a hurdle never crossed in Japanese history. If no critical mass supported amending Article 9, it is unlikely that enough people would support authorizing what can look like a “hostile” strategy even for self-defense.
Of course, officials are not sitting idly. They have slowly pushed Japan in the direction of so-called “cross-domain” operations -- operations that affect more than one domain (i.e. cyber and military domains) while keeping the change within the legal boundary.^{76} The 2018 version of the National Defense Program Guidelines (NDPG) focuses on some of the most important conventional military threats Japan faces, such as those from North Korea, Russia, and China.^{77} Traditionally, NDPG has emphasized senshu boei as in other defense papers, but the latest version suggested that a combined use of cyber and military retaliation is permissible. Among other things, it stated that in case of an armed attack, Japan would consider retaliation using kinetic, space, and cyber means.^{78}
However, close scrutiny reveals threes shortcomings with this arrangement. First, it does not promise a response to cyber attacks. Instead, it would only allow a mixed response to a military attack. In other words, it is not designed to deter cyber attacks. Second, by forcing Japan to wait to be attacked first, the arrangement falsely assumes that Japan would be able to retaliate after absorbing the first strike. Instead, a correct assumption should be that the first strike would remove Japan's ability to cyber-retaliate.^{79} Finally, for the SDF to synchronize operations between different domains and to do what it promises in the document, it would require revision to SDF Law to allow the establishment of a joint operations command or a permanent joint task force (JTF). This is because Article 22 of SDF Law would allow the government to set up JTFs only for specific missions (for example, for ballistic-
ssile defense missions). The legal reform, however, would be as cumbersome as I described above. While the strategic document seems to comply with provisions of the legal system, it has yet to be deemed as constitutional (or not). The latest strategic stance still comes with a severe restriction on the use of cyber force.
## Technical Obstacle to Deterrence by Active Defense
The other obstacle is technical, centered on the need to communicate the message of deterrence to right audiences. Deterrence requires Japan to ensure that the adversary receives its message and understands the conditions under which it would launch punitive measures. However, receivers of deterrent messages may have trouble with doing so because messages are coded, internet traffic is heavy, and there is much “noise” in cyberspace. Erica Borghard and Shawn Lonergan write that “even if a target state realizes it has been attacked, it is difficult to infer the intent behind a cyber signal based solely on an observed incursion.” This means that Japanese officials must make their message clearly communicated and act in consistent manner with the content of the message. Japan has two options to do so -- public and private communications with countries it seeks to dissuade. My analysis suggests that neither is easy.
On the one hand, Japan may opt to make public its threats to hackers in places like China and North Korea, declaring that it would fire punitive response to preemption, hoping that the “audiences” will get the message right and decide not to take action. Public communication is a good way to raise stakes, which is important because it increases audience costs, meaning that Japan would end up paying considerably if its threats go unheeded or if it fails to deliver the threats, so targets are likely to take the threat seriously. However, there are three problems with this process. First, it requires Japan to substantiate the damage of the initial attack that it sustained in order to make its action legitimate. To do so may Japan to reveal its capability and sensitive information, including the attack code used in the operation, when such information must be kept secret. While Japanese officials could deploy techniques like embedding unique signatures in the code to overcome the problem, they would still leave some trace of the operation on targets' network, meaning that the targets might be able to reuse and recycle the code in future operations. Second, public communication requires Japan to be willing to follow through the threat it issues, but the aforementioned legal problems make the follow-up action legally questionable and consequently make the threat less credible. This does not help deter attackers because it would allow them to simply ignore the threat. Alternative responses, such as indictments of foreign suspects and economic sanctions on individuals involved, could be costly; at the minimum, it would make Japan subject to retaliation. At a minimum, cyberspace escalation becomes likely, and worse, the heightened tension may as well spill over to other dimensions of international relations, including diplomatic, economic, and military.
On the other hand, Japan may seek to make threats of active defense privately, promising to retaliate against North Korean or Chinese attacks through diplomatic back-channels and crypto-messages in the attack code. Private communication may be effective because it permits bilateral communications in which no one else would know the negotiation, whether it succeeds or not, and in whose favor it ends up working. So actors are more likely to be willing to negotiate, and Japan can reassure them to quietly cease its attacks. The problem with private communication, however, is that attackers retain plausible deniability and face little incentive to admit wrongdoing because the whole thing is private. Private communication also involves the risk of getting outed by the attackers if they are not happy with the negotiation, which would embarrass Japan publicly. In other words, private communication gives Japan's adversaries a bargaining advantage. In sum, it is a risky move to threaten retaliation either publicly or privately. In both situations, escalation of cyberspace tension becomes likely.
Socio-political Obstacle to Deterrence by Active Defense
The technical challenge is serious because it leads to a political one of how to control escalation when Japan launches active defense measures. It is because it is in the interest of the Japanese government to avoid public outrage.^{82} Deterrence by active defense rests with the issuance of credible threats that clarify conditions under which Japan would attack back at aggressors. Good attackers know that Japanese officials are both willing and capable to carry out threats they issue because they have a variety of techniques and network devices to hide methods of active defense measures. For example, they know that Japan is able to quietly launch a malicious code into their networks in ways that appear to exploit vulnerabilities when it actually exploits another. The code can carry out a few critical missions, including spreading false information within the network, changing data in the attacker's systems without the latter realizing that they are getting inaccurate data.^{83} Therefore, if Japan makes a declaratory policy to punish an attacker, the attacker would be pressed hard to take the message as genuine (and hostile) and vow retaliation. As such, Japanese officials expect attackers to adopt an aggressive strategy and prepare for preemptive strikes. The tit-for-tat calculus increases the chance of escalation, generating a cycle of reactions and counter-reactions that may lead to a cybersecurity dilemma.^{84}
This is a serious problem because the fear of escalation can make many people highly risk-averse. Increasingly aware of their vulnerability, many Japanese have reasons to oppose escalation, from ordinary citizens to bankers to insurers. For instance, the financial world is known to display aversion toward escalation of violence.^{85} Many Japanese firms have already seen their systems compromised. Services and retail industries tend to sympathize with the financial world because they are among the most targeted.^{86} Furthermore, they face the likelihood that insurance costs will rise as a result of escalation, a problem that would pose challenges to consumers and insurers alike. In part due to widespread vulnerabilities in the industries, ordinary citizens have experienced repeated data breaches and anxities about cyber insurance premiums. They rely on property and casualty insurers who have faced an increasing number of claims. Not surprisingly, many insurers have declined to pay major claims, such as the NotPetya incident of 2018, and instead invoked “war exclusions” to decline coverage for hostile action. Cyberspace escalation would upset a number of ordinary people not only financially but psychologically. Citizens have experienced a heavy mental toll in the form of frustration and financial worry.^{87} According to a 2017 government survey, Japanese people considered the internet space as the most “frightening” (sic) place, more frightening than places like commercial streets and parking lots. They also considered cybercrimes as the most frightening crimes, more frightening than financial frauds and burglaries.^{88} Victims often turn to their government to blame because it is hard to hold foreign attackers accountable.
Opposition to active defense is a critical factor because it mounts a serious political challenge. As I discussed above, there is enough legal challenge with countermeasure options, which indicates a preexisting social foundation upon which grassroots movement may become a political opposition. Because it is hard to stop cyberspace escalation once it starts, people have enough reasons to feed extremist views on the debate when they exercise their rights to press governments. On the extreme side of the debate is the ideological left, represented by those who sympathize with the traditionally pacifist agenda of the Japanese Communist Party (JCP) and socialist members. JCP members and sympathizers have opposed a series of national security legislation for cybersecurity act, such as the Cybersecurity Basic Law, because they believe that they would allow Japan to operate with US forces more closely on cyber operations. They claim that, among other things, the United States has wrongfully treated cyber domain as a warfighting domain and that an expanded security alliance with the United States would draw Japan into unnecessary conflict. Seeing cyberspace escalation as the same as the militarization of it, they base their claim on the fact that the United States has preemptively (and allegedly illegally) conducted cyber attacks (i.e. NSA programs disclosed by Edward Snowden), possesses a strategy that unifies cyber operations with military ones, and conducts various intelligence, surveillance, and reconnaissance (ISR) operations on noncombatants across the globe. Furthermore,
they are concerned about the leak of Japanese IT companies' sensitive information to the United States when there is not enough protection extended to banking and retail sectors and not enough insurance coverage for victims of cyber fraud. While JCP and socialist advocates have long been pushed to the corner of Japanese political party dynamics, their views and influence across the Japanese society on the way legal decisions are made in the area of national security should not be underestimated. While these views have never become a majority view in Japan, the broader message of alarmism about aggressive strategy continues to resonate with the electorate.
## Conclusion
In this article, I showed that Japan's current defense system has not worked adequately to deter cyber attacks because of its heavy reliance on passive defense strategy. While passive defense is useful for rejecting hostile actions, it does little to deter them. Deterrence by punishment requires the use of active defense countermeasures, but they have not been the strategy of choice for legal and technical reasons. The challenges that Japan's legal system and technical difficulties pose have been tremendous; with bureaucratic reform made in recent years on the incremental basis, Japanese networks remain as vulnerable as before, consistently failing to curb the incoming hostility.
Given the high stakes to correct the course, reform may be forthcoming, albeit slowly. The legal reform is hard to sell to the Japanese public because it has significant bearings on domestic politics and constraints on the use of force at home and because the existing legal system is so embedded in the society. People in Japan have reasons to oppose government policy to adopt aggressive cyber strategy in a democratic process. On top of this, the technical challenges have proven themselves to be so complex that drastic change in policy may be difficult to achieve in the short period of time.
Certainly, Japan's case presents an important case study for a broader subset of democratic nations confronted with the challenge of increasing digital hostility. Japan's example illustrates the difficulties of overcoming existing legal hurdles and technical constraints inherent in cyberspace. In this respect, this article serves as a reminder of the need to probe options of dealing with cyber attacks with deterrent threats. Even though the article spells a number of reasons for us to be skeptical about the drastic change in Japan's cyber defense strategy, it may encourage more studies on the topic to expand our research agenda in ways that may lead to additional insights about how cyber deterrence may work in the future.

metadata.abstract: I investigate reasons why Japan does not use "active-defense" cyber strategy for the purpose of cyberspace deterrence. I show that the reason has much to do with the passive nature of cyber strategy best characterized as "denial defense," a strategic posture designed to deny attacks by defensive methods. I offer three reasons for this strategic choice. The first is the way the law works in Japan. The legal system, including the constitution, is the cornerstone of passive defense. All the reforms made in recent years to buttress Japan's cyber policy have been within the existing legal framework. The second reason is the enormous technical constraints that Japan face on the use of cyber force. The final reason has much to do with the difficulty of sending credible threats to target audiences, reassuring the public, and controlling cyberspace escalation. In 2016, Japan's Ministry of Defense (MOD) realized that foreign agents had penetrated its communications network known as the Defense Information Infrastructure (DII). The DII was supposed to be more secure than private networks, many of which had been compromised elsewhere. It consisted of an external system linking the internet and an internal system that allowed defense officials to electronically communicate. Normally these systems were used separately, but officials were using them interchangeably when the hackers infiltrated. The initial point of attack was through computer networks at the National Defense Medical College, from where the attackers moved to penetrate the network of the Japan Ground Self-Defense Force (JGSDF). This was despite the fact that JGSDF had limited external connections to prevent precisely this kind of attack. Although the MOD denied the incident, news media pointed out that critical information about ground operations had been stolen within hours of attack.1 What was surprising about the incident was not the vulnerability of Japan's defense system but the absence of a “real” response to prevent further attacks.2 After locating the attack origin in China, the Japanese government decided against urging Beijing to stop or taking retaliatory strikes, and instead did what it had always done -- deny incidents and beef up defense. Japan's cautiousness was in stark contrast to the growing openness of Western governments to the option of countermeasures -- defined here as acts of proportionally responding to cyber attackers to compel them to desist -- measures that include honeypots to lure in attackers for observation and quarantine, “hacking-back” at the origin of attacks, and “dye-packs,” a malware in its networks' decoy file that traces attackers.3 Today, the contrast looks even more stark when we consider the fact that, while Japan is among many countries with the ability to launch cyber countermeasures,4 there is no record that it has ever used it. That creates a puzzle; if Japan is capable of attacking back to deter cyber attacks, why does it not use it? What makes it unwilling to use the power that others have used elsewhere? Is it because Japan's defense is simply weak? Probably not, because Japanese technocrats do have skills to operate as refined hackers. How about international legal restrictions? Not quite, because international law has little power to enforce rules on cyber retaliations. While there are many academic works on Japan's defense policy and capability, there has been a marked hole in the literature on Japan's cyber deterrence strategy. In fact, analysis of Japan's security policy, particularly one in the Western scholarship, has been so focused on the military aspects of it that the scholarship on Japan's cyber defense has been under-developed.^{5} In this paper, I seek to fill the void by explaining why Japan has been unwilling to launch countermeasures as a means of deterring cyber attacks. My answer to the puzzle consists of three dimensions. First, Japan's current defense system has not worked well to deter cyber attacks. Granted, cyber deterrence is known to be extremely hard, and Japan's case is no exception. Data shows that the average number of breaches per attempts on Japanese networks is extremely high at 96.8%, a near certainty that a cyber attacks would hit the target. The number of attack attempts has been mostly steady over the years, meaning that there is a constant flow of incoming attacks. In other words, while Japan's cyber defense strategy may be denying some illicit traffic, it is not deterring new attackers. Had the current strategy have been working, we would have seen an overall reduction of attack incidents. Second, the failure to deter cybercrimes has much to do with the passive nature of cyber strategy best characterized as “denial defense,” a strategic posture designed to deny foreign attacks by defensive methods. Denial defense centers on the use of “passive defense” actions to minimize damage, rather than “active defense” that involves attacking back. This is because Japan has spent decades building denial defense capability through new laws, organizational reform, government-wide training systems, and collaboration with the private sector. While denial defense is useful for rejecting hostile actions, it does little to deter them -- by imposing such costs on attackers that they cease operations. Instead, it is active defense that carries this retaliatory ability. The primary reason why Japan's cyber deterrence strategy has not worked well is because it has invested exclusively in passive defense. Finally, I point out three factors that keep Japan's cyber warriors from active defense operations. The first is the way the law works. The legal system, including the constitution, is the cornerstone of passive defense. Consistent with the postwar doctrine of defensive defense, or senshu boei,^{6} the existing legal system keeps cyber strategy strictly in line with passive defense. The legal constraint on active defense is buttressed by the second factor -- the enormous technical constraints that cyber warriors face on the use of force. The constraints come from the difficulty of sending credible threats to target audiences, which leads to the challenge of reassuring the public that they will not be attacked and controlling cyberspace escalation. In other words, the legal, technical, and socio-political hurdles are the reason why Japanese cyber strategy is stuck with passive defense operations. The purpose of this paper is not policy advocacy; I do not call for revision of the existing system to make way for active defense strategy. I do not assume that such revision ought to be made, either. Instead, my aim is analytical. I intend to critically assess a set of key factors that keep the counter-measure options off the table when they may be needed to deter criminal acts. I do so by presenting a detailed analysis of legal and technical challenges that are unique to Japanese context. In so doing, I combine the academic research on cybersecurity with the literature of Japanese defense policy as an intellectual source of inquiry. The analysis proceeds in five steps. First, I show how passive defense informs Japan's cyber strategy. Second, I present data to show why the current strategy has not worked adequately to deter attackers. Third, I explain how the legal system reinforces the status quo with passive defense. Fourth, I describe how technical challenges make it hard for the country to adopt active defense strategy. Finally, I conclude.
